study.title: A case for routine microbial diagnostics: Results from antimicrobial susceptibility testing in post-traumatic wound infections at a Ugandan tertiary care hospital

design.inclusion_criteria_text: Patients of all age groups on the MNRH orthopedic/trauma unit who developed clinical signs of wound infection (e.g. erythema /pus discharge) and/or fever.
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Patients without clinical signs of wound infection but fever due to malaria or acute, untreated tuberculosis and patients participating in another study.

eligibility.population: Patients of all age groups on the MNRH orthopedic/trauma unit with clinical signs of wound infection (e.g. erythema /pus discharge) and/or fever.
eligibility.intervention: Empirical antimicrobial treatments, targeted treatments following microbiology testing and surgical treatments.
eligibility.comparator: Empirical treatment prior to AST-guided therapy.

populations.description: All patients with post-traumatic wound infections admitted to the orthopedic/trauma unit at Mulago National Referral Hospital.
populations.comorbidities_key: HIV positive: 5.7%; Diabetes mellitus: 3.2%; Other pre-existing conditions: 3.2%

provenance.section_heading: Table 1. Demographic and clinical characteristics of study population
provenance.text_snippet: Demographic and clinical characteristics of study population (n = 124)

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Antimicrobial susceptibility tests were performed using a Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method based on the 2020 CLSI standards.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: Clinical outcome categorized as complete recovery, minor disability, moderate disability, major disability, or death.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Wound swabs taken from all sites with clinical signs of infection by trained staff following the Levine method.
lab_methods.culture_method: Wound swabs inoculated onto Chocolate, Blood and MacConkey agar and incubated in a 5–7% CO2 incubator. Blood cultures performed on BACTEC9120 or FX40 system and sub cultured onto Chocolate, Blood and MacConkey agar if positive.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Manual using colony morphology, gram stain characteristics and conventional biochemical tests according to laboratory SOPs and automated BD Phoenix instrument.
lab_methods.contamination_handling: As wounds following trauma are a non-sterile environment, contaminants or skin-colonizing isolates might be sampled; results from wound swabs should be interpreted with caution.
lab_methods.lab_capacity_notes: Laboratory constraints: some pathogens not identified to genus level; ESBL production could not be confirmed by reference method.

provenance.section_heading: Table 2. Most prevalent pathogens (n>20 isolates) and their resistance towards selected antimicrobials.
provenance.text_snippet: E. coli N = 48 Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime2 43/45 (95.7)

provenance.text_snippet: E. coli N = 48 Gentamicin 22/40 (55.0)

provenance.section_heading: Table 2. Most prevalent pathogens (n>20 isolates) and their resistance towards selected antimicrobials.
provenance.text_snippet: Acinetobacter spp. N = 43 Gentamicin 32/39 (82.1)

provenance.section_heading: Table 2. Most prevalent pathogens (n>20 isolates) and their resistance towards selected antimicrobials.
provenance.text_snippet: Klebsiella spp. N = 34 Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime2 30/32 (93.8)

provenance.section_heading: Table 2. Most prevalent pathogens (n>20 isolates) and their resistance towards selected antimicrobials.
provenance.text_snippet: P. aeruginosa N = 28 Gentamicin 11/24 (45.8)

amr_proportions.notes: Vancomycin resistance in 85% of Enterococcus spp. isolates.

provenance.section_heading: 3.2 Type and prevalence of pathogens and resistance patterns
provenance.text_snippet: The majority (n = 17, 85%) of Enterococcus spp. isolates displayed vancomycin resistance.

provenance.section_heading: 3.2 Type and prevalence of pathogens and resistance patterns
provenance.text_snippet: While Staphylococcus aureus was rarely isolated in our population (n = 19), four (21.1%) isolates were methicillin resistant.

morbidity.definition_text: Minor, moderate, or major disability at discharge.
morbidity.notes: Only 12 patients (9.7%) recovered completely; 89.5% left with some disability.

provenance.section_heading: Table 3. Clinical outcomes of study participants (n = 124).
provenance.text_snippet: Minor disability 62 (50.0%), Moderate disability 28 (22.6%), Major disability 21 (16.9%)

mortality.definition_text: Death during hospital stay (intra-operative cardiac arrest).
mortality.notes: A 23-year-old male patient died intra-operatively due to cardiac arrest.

provenance.section_heading: Table 3. Clinical outcomes of study participants (n = 124).
provenance.text_snippet: Death 1 (0.8%)

length_of_stay.notes: Median length of stay on the ward was 22 days (IQR 15–41 days).

provenance.text_snippet: The median length of stay on the ward was 22 days (IQR 15–41 days).

interventions.description: Routine microbial diagnostics and AST performed for all patients with wound infections.

provenance.text_snippet: Upon review of AST results, the majority of patients (n = 111, 95.7%) required a change of antimicrobial treatment.

policy_capacity.status_text: Microbiological diagnostics not routinely available; laboratory constraints in pathogen identification and ESBL confirmation.

provenance.text_snippet: Due to laboratory constraints some pathogens were not identified to genus level, including Enterococcus spp. and Acinetobacter spp., and ESBL production could unfortunately not be confirmed by a reference method.

policy_capacity.status_text: Uganda implemented a structured national AMR surveillance program in alignment with WHO GLASS in 2015.

provenance.text_snippet: Despite being the first African country to implement a structured national AMR surveillance program in alignment with the WHO Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS) in 2015 [8]

policy_capacity.status_text: National Action Plan on AMR published in 2018; strategic objectives on surveillance, diagnostics and access to antimicrobials.

provenance.text_snippet: A National Action Plan (NAP) on AMR was published in 2018 [9] and set strategic objectives on surveillance, diagnostics and access to antimicrobials [10].

codes.subtheme: resistance patterns and rates by pathogen/antibiotic
codes.summary: High rates of antimicrobial resistance were found across gram-negative and gram-positive species towards the most common empiric antibiotics.

evidence_quotes.quote: With 98% resistance towards ceftriaxone and 51% resistance towards gentamicin, a large proportion of all pathogens demonstrated resistance, or were intrinsically resistant, to the most commonly used empiric antibiotics.
evidence_quotes.section: 3.2 Type and prevalence of pathogens and resistance patterns

codes.location_context: Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala, Uganda

provenance.section_heading: 3.2 Type and prevalence of pathogens and resistance patterns
provenance.text_snippet: With 98% resistance towards ceftriaxone and 51% resistance towards gentamicin, a large proportion of all pathogens demonstrated resistance, or were intrinsically resistant, to the most commonly used empiric antibiotics.

codes.subtheme: inappropriate use, IPC gaps, diagnostics delays, policy failures, supply chain, workforce, patient factors
codes.summary: Empirical antibiotic treatment is commonly based on clinical judgement without knowledge of pathogen and resistance patterns, and self-prescription is prevalent.

evidence_quotes.quote: Empirical antibiotic treatment on the ward was commonly based on clinical judgement without knowledge of pathogen and resistance patterns. The ability to perform microbial testing was limited, since it is an unaffordable out-of-pocket expense for most patients in this setting.

Over 80% of them bought antimicrobials directly in community drug shops or pharmacies without a medical prescription, which underlines the high prevalence of self-prescription in our sample, similar to the available literature [19,20].

codes.location_context: Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala, Uganda

provenance.text_snippet: Empirical antibiotic treatment on the ward was commonly based on clinical judgement without knowledge of pathogen and resistance patterns.

codes.summary: Nosocomial infections are common, possibly due to long hospital stays and suboptimal infection prevention and control.

evidence_quotes.quote: Nosocomial infections might be more common in Uganda as hospital stays tend to be long due to treatment delays and IPC is often not optimal [44].

provenance.text_snippet: Nosocomial infections might be more common in Uganda as hospital stays tend to be long due to treatment delays and IPC is often not optimal [44].

codes.summary: Routine microbial diagnostics and AST enabled targeted therapy and diversification of treatment options.

evidence_quotes.quote: The use of AST in our study enabled the diversification of treatment options and guided clinical decision-making.

codes.location_context: Mulago National Referral Hospital, Kampala, Uganda

provenance.text_snippet: The use of AST in our study enabled the diversification of treatment options and guided clinical decision-making.

codes.summary: Uganda has a National Action Plan on AMR and participates in GLASS, but lacks routine lab-based surveillance and comprehensive stewardship programs.

evidence_quotes.quote: Despite being the first African country to implement a structured national AMR surveillance program in alignment with the WHO Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS) in 2015 [8], the magnitude of AMR in Uganda remains largely unknown due to a lack of access to microbiological diagnostics.

provenance.text_snippet: Despite being the first African country to implement a structured national AMR surveillance program in alignment with the WHO Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS) in 2015 [8], the magnitude of AMR in Uganda remains largely unknown due to a lack of access to microbiological diagnostics.

notes_flags.detail: No SSI incidence rates or events/denominator reported.

provenance.text_snippet: The aim of this study was to determine pathogen prevalence and antibiotic resistance patterns in patients with wound infections following trauma at a national referral hospital in Kampala, Uganda.

notes_flags.detail: No explicit follow-up window for SSI ascertainment.

provenance.text_snippet: Follow-up study visits were conducted two and four days after enrolment by the study staff on the ward. The final study visit was done upon discharge from the unit.

notes_flags.detail: No cost or economic outcome data reported.

provenance.text_snippet: No cost or economic outcome data reported.

notes_flags.detail: No stewardship guideline adherence rates reported.

provenance.text_snippet: Comprehensive antimicrobial stewardship (AMS) is not routinely performed at Ugandan hospitals [11].

provenance_index.text_snippet: The aim of this study was to determine pathogen prevalence and antibiotic resistance patterns in patients with wound infections following trauma at a national referral hospital in Kampala, Uganda.
